blackkm7 wrote:

>By random chance I had a run of the full 7 outputs find a solution.  
>When examining it, compared to all the failed attempts, and also 
>looking at the differences in the 1 output solutions that worked or 
>didn't, it turns out that this problem apparently requires the BIAS 
>node.
>  
>
Yeh that makes sense.

[...]

>Luckily I remembered reading something in the FAQ in the 
>section: "Can I start NEAT with some inputs disconnected? (IMPORTANT)"
>that tells how to overcome the node elimination problem.  When I 
>implemented this sugestion, all new runs quickly got past the 
>former "permanent" local optimum.
>
> <>It still takes a long time to actually evolve a winner each run, 
> but  I now have confidence that it probably will find a solution given

This is good news. Another thought, what values are you inputing into 
the network? If you are using 0 and 1 then you might want to change this 
to 0.1 and 0.9, or at least use 0.1 instead of 0.0.  Zero causes 
problems because it cannot be transformed by connection weights - 
anything*0 = 0.

In fact this might be why the bias signal is so important at the moment.

Also, you're probably doing this already, but just in case - for the 
output nodes just take anything less than 0.5 as a zero and anything 
greater then 0.5 as a 1.0.

Actually this problem is more difficult than I first thought because you 
want generate the correct combination of LEDs for values above 9. So 
that the network has to do extra work to figure out that 10 gives the 
same result as 0. It might be kinder to NEAT of you tried input values 
of 0 to 9 before moving on to the more difficult problem you currently have.

Colin
